article.title: Machine learning algorithm to characterize antimicrobial resistance associated with the International Space Station surface microbiome
funding: NASA grant 16-ROSBFP_GL-0005: NNH16ZTT001N-FG Appendix G: Solicitation of Proposals for Flight and Ground Space Biology Research (Award Number: 80NSSC19K0883)
The Translational Research Institute for Space Health through NASA Cooperative Agreement NNX16AO69A (T-0404)
ESA Space Omics Topical Team, funded by the ESA grant/contract 4000131202/20/NL/PG/pt “Space Omics: Towards an integrated ESA/NASA –omics database for spaceflight and ground facilities experiments”
NASA grants (NNX16AO69A, NNX14AH50G, NNX17AB26G), the NIH (R01AI151059, U01DA053941) and Igor Tulchinsky and the WorldQuant Foundation
article.abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has a detrimental impact on human health on Earth and it is equally concerning in other environments such as space habitat due to microgravity, radiation and confinement, especially for long-distance space travel.

sections.introduction: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has a detrimental impact on human health on Earth and it is equally concerning in other environments such as space habitat due to microgravity, radiation and confinement, especially for long-distance space travel.
sections.methods: The paired-end 100-bp metagenomic reads from NCBI Short Read Archive (SRA) under the bio-project number PRJNA438545 were processed with Trimmomatic to trim adapter sequences and low-quality ends, with a minimum Phred score of 20 across the entire length of the read used as a quality cut-off.
sections.results: Our results in PMA treated samples revealed AMR dominance in the last flight for Kalamiella piersonii, a bacteria related to urinary tract infection in humans.
sections.discussion: Many ARGs that present high probability but low sequence identity to known sequences will be missed using traditional ‘best-hit’ approaches that require a high degree of sequence identity.

article.insights_summary: This study used a deep learning approach to identify antimicrobial resistance genes associated with the International Space Station surface microbiome. The results showed that antimicrobial resistance dominance was observed in the last flight for Kalamiella piersonii, a bacteria related to urinary tract infection in humans. The study also found that many ARGs that present high probability but low...
